reasoning: The critique targets Section 2.5’s psychological support for ‘eutopia recedes’ and for the claim that future inhabitants might not notice value-loss due to preference adaptation/engineering. That material is supportive but not load-bearing for the essay’s main case (which also relies heavily on moral-pluralism examples of catastrophe, the multiplicative/fragility model, and the Section 3 argument that many plausible value functions are ‘fussy’). So centrality is modest. On the attacked slice, the critique has some bite: it highlights a potential unfalsifiability/one-way-ratchet worry (apparent satisfaction can be reinterpreted as engineered), and notes that agents with better models may resent/notice manipulation—these points plausibly weaken the psychological move. But the essay already partially hedges that this analogy may be misleading and doesn’t make the psychological claim strictly necessary, limiting strength. The critique’s empirical assertions about ‘stable human drives’ and inevitability of manipulation becoming salient are plausible but not decisive, so correctness is fairly high but not near-1. It is clearly written, mostly focused, and has little dead weight; the paternalism warning is an additional normative implication but still connected to the same epistemic complaint.
title: Hedonic treadmill and preference engineering assumptions lack empirical grounding
